III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4157 Behavior management.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
Description procedures that describe the institution’s behavior management
system. The policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to all residents,
their families, and referring agencies.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Staff 1 was verbally confrontational and escalated Youth A rather
than use verbal de-escalation techniques as trained.
Investigation I contacted identified witness, Methodist’s Case Manager, via
phone on 10/04/23 asking her to identify the youth and direct care
staff involved. Case Manager recalled the situation and identified
Youth A. She said the staff involved was female but was unable
to positively identify her.
On 10/9/23 I notified Chief Administrator of the allegation and
requested names of all the female direct care staff who worked on
9/19/23. Chief Administrator identified Staff 1 as the person
involved.
I notified Complainant, also Youth A’s private agency adoption
worker, that I was assigned this investigation. She had no
additional concerns about the facility.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
I arrived at the facility on 10/09/23 and interviewed Case
Manager. She said on 9/19/23 she facilitated the monthly visit
between Youth A and Complainant in the clinical building. “Youth
A is autistic. He got upset because his worker would not take him
off campus. He walked out. Complainant and I followed him
outdoors. Youth A was angry. Complainant tried to de-escalate
him. I tried to get him to return to Clinical. He refused. Staff 1
was outside.” Youth A asked Staff 1 to confirm in front of
Complainant that he’s been ‘good’ (and deserves to go off-
campus). Staff 1 mentioned that earlier in the day, Youth A called
her out of her name, and she redirected him to continue visiting
with Complainant. Youth A became more upset because Staff 1
did not affirm him. “I suggested the worker and I remove
ourselves. We walked back to clinical. Complainant was shocked
at Youth A’s behavior and remarked that she had never seen him
act that way. Complainant did not mention anything about Staff
1’s interaction with the youth.
On 10/05/23, Case Manager said she attended a virtual meeting
with Complainant. During the meeting Complainant complimented
her approach with Youth A on 9/19/23 and mentioned that she
thought Youth A’s behavior escalated while he was talking with
Staff 1. In the meeting, Case Manager said she verbally
supported Staff 1 and her ability to avoid ‘feeding in’ to Youth A’s
motives to get off-campus. However, Complainant said she
viewed Staff 1 as ‘going back and forth debating’ with the youth.
2

Case Manager denied Staff 1 was debating with the youth.
Rather she said she was setting boundaries and being direct.
Case Manager believes Complainant misinterpreted the
interaction.
I attempted to interview Youth A, but he was having an emotional
breakdown while I was at the facility. I heard a boy screaming,
crying, and banging on the window of the interview room and was
told it was Youth A. I walked outdoors and observed Youth A
standing red-faced against a tree screaming at the top of his
lungs. Staff were outdoors trying to de-escalate him.
I interviewed Residential Director who was outdoors on 9/19/23
when Youth A became angry with Complainant and walked out of
the visit. “Youth A was banging on doors and screaming out of
control like he is now, threatening to destroy Staff 1’s car. Like
Staff 1, I tried to limit-set with him too,” he explained. Residential
Director did not view Staff 1’s behavior as inappropriate.
I interviewed Staff 1 who has worked at the facility for five years.
Outdoors, she said Youth A was threatening to break the windows
out of her personal vehicle. “I asked him not to step by my car,
that I would not allow him to destroy it. He came within arms-
reach of my car. I got between him and my car. He backed up
and I told him not to touch my car. Youth A veered away and
continued screaming and hollering. I asked why he was upset.
Residential Director was there.”
I asked Staff 1 if Complainant was within earshot of her verbal
interaction with Youth A. She said she may have heard her shout
and direct him not to touch her car, but otherwise Complainant
was not close enough to hear the interaction. Staff 1 denied
causing or escalating Youth A’s acting out behaviors.
I reviewed the written Verbal Escalation Continuum. It indicates
when a youth shows an unwillingness to cooperate or follow
instructions, appropriate staff interventions include limit setting
and redirection.
Analysis There is no evidence Staff 1 caused Youth A’s behavior to
escalate on 9/19/23. By setting limits and redirecting, Staff 1
responded appropriately to Youth A’s attempts to manipulate
Complainant, threats to destroy Staff 1’s car and his general
unwillingness to follow directions.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
